learning_outcomes.description: Perform systematic clinical examinations, create problem lists, develop logical diagnostic plans, execute appropriate diagnostic sampling, interpret clinical findings and diagnostic test results, and construct defensible therapeutic and management plans relevant to diseases and disorders involving the health, welfare and productivity of both individual animals and groups/herds/flocks.
Identify risk factors that contribute to disease outbreaks in groups/herds/flocks.
Create and critique group/herd/flock health programs designed to maximise productivity, animal welfare and disease prevention and control.

Self-evaluate your personal and professional development through proactive engagement in the feedback process to identify strengths, gaps, and challenges with respect to Day-One readiness and enact learning plans to build on strengths, fill gaps, and overcome challenges.

assessments.assessment_title: UQ VETS Gatton Production Animal Service (PAS) - Clinical Internal Rotation
assessments.due_date:
Students must complete and submit the following via MyKnowledge Map:

  • A minimum of TWO (2) feedback forms per week of the rotation (SIX in total). Forms will not be accepted if insufficient data is included.
  • Self‑evaluation of performance using the rubric, with justification for scores provided in writing.

All forms must be submitted by 5 pm on the final day of your rotation.
assessments.task_description:
This assessment is a 3-week clinical internal rotation where the student will attend the UQ Gatton Production Animal Service (PAS).  This rotation incorporates a range of clinical activities to build skills and knowledge in production animal practice (focusing on ruminants, camelids and pigs). 

During this rotation, students will attend a combination of PAS Clinic, structured learning activities, and 4 after-hours shifts. Details of the rotation roster and activities can be found on the VETS5024 Blackboard site.

In this task, you are required to self-evaluate your performance, evaluating what went well and where you can improve. When self-evaluating, use the rubric (available on Blackboard) with descriptors of the expected behaviours, skills and characteristics required to achieve that level. You must provide a sentence or two to justify your scores by describing how your involvement in activities demonstrates the indicated level of achievement within each criterion.

During this rotation, students will submit a minimum of TWO (2) feedback forms per week of the rotation. Forms will not be accepted if there is insufficient data included in the submission. Assessments are to be submitted to a range of veterinary mentors over the 3-week rotation. 

These evaluations may then be reviewed by the attending clinicians to agree with the assessment or disagree and adjust the self-evaluation as needed.

Feedback form(s) may be generated by the attending clinician(s) after consultation with the course coordinator.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students must complete and submit the following via MyKnowledge Map:
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.late_submission: A penalty of 10% of the maximum possible mark will be deducted per 24 hours from time submission is due for up to 7 days. After 7 days, you will receive a mark of 0.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date: Students will attend this exam during their time on PAS rotation.
assessments.task_description:
The 1 hour Case Management Scenarios Exam will consist of questions built around production animal cases. Assessable material will include learning content delivered during the final year clinical rotation, placements and content delivered in pre-requisite courses. 

Students will have 4 case scenarios to work through in 1 hour. The exam will cover individual and herd/flock medicine, surgery, reproduction and obstetrics in cattle, small ruminants, pigs, poultry and camelids. 

For each scenario, students will be provided with a high-quality image(s) or video(s) and a brief case history typical of what they would receive in practice.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

assessments.due_date: Students will present their case scenario during their PAS rotation.
assessments.task_description:
The focus of the case presentation will be production animal cases only - ruminants, chickens, camelids or pigs.

As part of their reflective task, students will prepare a 5-6 minute presentation of a production animal case that they have attended during their VETS5024 UQ VETS Gatton PAS Rotation or as assigned.

Mandatory content includes:

  • date the case was attended
  • the veterinary clinic and attending veterinary mentor
  • case history
  • signalment
  • presenting complaint
  • All relevant clinical exam data / assessment(s)
  • problem list
  • differential list
  • diagnostics
  • most likely differential
  • treatment and management plan


The presentation must also demonstrate reflection on the case approach and treatment outcomes. This may include a review of case-relevant literature, appropriate references, and noting how the case approach may be honed when attending future cases.

Owner and attending veterinary consent must be obtained before any photos or video content is taken of private property or animals. Confidentiality of clients and animals must be maintained at all times. 

Additional details on the case presentation can be found in the VETS5024 Blackboard site.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Students are to attend on presentation day. The presentations will be recorded on the day.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.due_date: This assessment must be completed by the end of the 3-week VETS5024 clinical rotation.
assessments.task_description:
The Regulatory Medicine Module requires students to work through a series of self-directed activities.

This capstone module aims to consolidate and contextualise the legal framework in which registered veterinarians must practice, such that students understand and can practise in compliance with legal requirements.

On completion of this module, students will be able to:

  1. Identify the key veterinary roles that involve legislative governance
  2. Nominate and briefly describe the function of the Acts and other statutes associated with these roles
  3. Based on various scenarios faced, describe specific features of how they should practise to ensure compliance with legislative requirements
  4. Advise clients, staff and other relevant people as to how they can comply with legislative requirements


At the end of the module, the student will answer a series of questions in a Quiz format, to identify their level of understanding of the material and ensure competency for graduation. The quiz will be delivered through Blackboard, is Pass/Fail, and requires an 80% mark to pass.

This assessment must be complete by the end of the 3-week VETS5024 clinical rotation.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: This quiz is delivered through the VETS5024 Blackboard site.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.assessment_title: Animal Health Australia Exotic Animal Disease Foundation Course
assessments.due_date: This assessment must be completed by the end of the 3-week VETS5024 clinical rotation.
assessments.task_description:
The Animal Health Australia Exotic Animal Disease Module is embedded in the Regulatory Medicine Module and requires students to work through a series of self-directed activities.

To ensure that all UQ BVSc (Hons) graduates have the required Emergency Animal Disease (EAD) competencies, Animal Health Australia has allowed access for students to complete the EAD Foundation online training module by following this link http://aha.canopihr.com.au.

All students are required to complete both Parts 1 and 2 of these modules. 

Students must visit all pages and achieve 80% on the final assessment to pass the course. Multiple attempts of the final quiz (and the progressive quizzes) are permitted.

On successful completion of this training, students will receive a Certificate of Completion, which must be uploaded via the VETS5024 Blackboard submission portal. Create the file as a PDF file with your name included in the file name.

This assessment must be completed by the end of the 3-week VETS5024 clinical rotation.


Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This task has been designed to be challenging, authentic and complex. Whilst students may use AI and/or MT technologies, successful completion of assessment in this course will require students to critically engage in specific contexts and tasks for which artificial intelligence will provide only limited support and guidance.

A failure to reference generative AI or MT use may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.

To pass this assessment, students will be required to demonstrate detailed comprehension of their written submission independent of AI and MT tools.
assessments.submission_guidelines: Upload your Certificate of Completion through the submission point in Blackboard Ultra.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to apply for an extension.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to apply for an extension.

assessments.task_description:
The Capstone Examination will provide a comprehensive evaluation of students’ clinical problem-solving skills, regardless of species or discipline.

The exam assesses core knowledge, clinical reasoning, and the ability to diagnose and manage conditions commonly encountered during the first year of practice. The exam will include contributions from the following courses: VETS5015, VETS5020, VETS5024, VETS5028, VETS5029, and VETS5030.

Exam Structure

  • Two parts, each containing 84 multiple-choice (MCQ) questions
  • Each part will take approximately two hours
  • Questions from each course will be weighted according to the course’s unit value

For sample questions, exam duration details, and the distribution of questions per section, please refer to your course Blackboard site.

Use of Artificial Intelligence (AI)  

This assessment task is to be completed in-person. The use of generative Artificial Intelligence (AI) or Machine Translation (MT) tools will not be permitted. Any attempted use of AI or MT may constitute student misconduct under the Student Code of Conduct.
assessments.deferral_or_extension: You may be able to defer this exam.
assessments.additional_info: You may be able to defer this exam.

learning_activities.topic:
UQ VETS Gatton Production Animal Service - Clinical Internal Rotation

Three weeks of structured learning and clinical placement at Production Animal Service (PAS) UQ Gatton. Investigate and manage production animal clinical cases at the UQ Gatton Campus and surrounding farms.


Sub-activity: During this rotation, you will be attending in-hours and after-hours consultation at the UQ veterinary clinic and on farm. There will also be an element of structured and self-directed learning activates.

Learning outcomes: L01, L02, L03, L04
